optionContent.general-partnership: In a general partnership two or more people share ownership of a single business and are jointly responsible for its assets and liabilities. [Learn more about General Partnerships.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/general-partnership)
optionContent.c-corporation: A traditional Corporation (C Corp) is more complex than other business types and is generally suggested for larger, established companies with multiple employees. [Learn more about Corporations.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/c-corporation-c-corp)
optionContent.limited-liability-company: An LLC is one of the most common business structures. In an LLC, there can be one or multiple owners, and they are not personally liable for company debts. [Learn more about Limited Liability Companies.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/limited-liability-company-llc)
optionContent.limited-liability-partnership: Limited Liability Partnerships have general partners who own and operate the business, and limited partners who invest in the business, both types of partners have limited liability. [Learn more about Limited Liability Partnerships.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/llp-lp)
optionContent.limited-partnership: Limited Partnerships have general partners who own and operate the business, and limited partners who invest in the business but have limited liability and oversight. [Learn more about Limited Partners.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/llp-lp)
optionContent.s-corporation: A Corporation with an S Corporation Tax Designation (S Corp) is similar to a C Corporation except that the business is not taxed separately from the owners. S Corps are also very similar to Limited Liability Companies (LLCs), but with more limitations. You may elect S Corp status separately after you form and register for tax and employer purposes. [Learn more about Corporations with an S designation.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/s-corporation-s-corp)
optionContent.sole-proprietorship: In a sole proprietorship you alone own the company and are responsible for its assets and liabilities. [Learn more about Sole Proprietorships.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/sole-proprietorship)
optionContent.nonprofit: Nonprofits are a type of C Corporation, but unlike a for-profit corporation, a nonprofit organization has a mission to benefit the public rather than generating profit. Nonprofits belong to the public, are governed by a board of trustees, and can qualify for tax-exemption. [Learn more about Nonprofits.](https://business.nj.gov/pages/nonprofit)

default.placeholder: If you are an LLC, Corporation, nonprofit, LP, or LLP, we will automatically add your formation documents once you [Form Your Business](/tasks/form-business-entity) on our site.

default.noteForBusinessesFormedOutsideNavigator: Your profile helps us make recommendations for your business. We do not submit information for registration.
default.permitsAndLicensesSubText: Answer a few questions to find out what licenses and permits you may need and discover funding programs to help your business grow. New items will appear on your Starter Kit or your For You section.
